discourse_list.title: [Informal Poll] Alternative Options to the Current DAI Savings Rate (DSR)

content.content: This poll aims to assess whether the community believes that offering other DSR options, such as notice accounts with different unwinding periods and rates, would be attractive to DAI holders. Currently, there is one DSR option offered to DAI holders: instant access at a predetermined rate (e.g. 1%). The proposed solution would be similar to notice accounts, which can have different unwinding periods at a range of rates. For example, a 30-day notice DSR account could earn 1.50%, instead of 1.00%, to compensate for the extra 30 days of notice/liquidity that they are providing. The client would request/call the funds and be able to withdraw the DAI locked in the DSR in 30 days. This in turn would allow Maker’s ALM team to have a longer duration asset; for example, instead of investing in MMFs it could invest the funds in 1-month treasury, or it could continue to invest in MMFs and have a withdrawal table that allows it to plan for those liquidity events. There have been efforts to create a fixed-term, fixed-rate product, but given changing market conditions, this could be an alternative/complementary product with a possibly lower cost and simpler coding solution that could achieve the same goal. Do you believe that offering additional DSR options, such as notice accounts with different unwinding periods, would be attractive to DAI holders?     Yes No Maybe     0 voters     Do you think that notice accounts, rather than term accounts, would better align with DAI’s investment options?     Yes No Maybe     0 voters
content.GPT-summary: The author of the post is conducting an informal poll to gather feedback from the community on whether offering additional DSR options, such as notice accounts with different unwinding periods, would be attractive to DAI holders. The proposed solution would allow Maker's ALM team to have a longer duration asset and plan for liquidity events. The post also includes two poll questions for the community to answer.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback
None
None

content.content: Maker would benefit from a discussion around how it intends to manage Dai liquidity. We imagine this would come out of the S&L scope meetings, specifically with regards to its ALM model. We are not sure regarding the characterization of a notice model as less complex or less challenging than a term product. Below is a prototype of a Term Dai product that would support MakerDAO to manage Dai liquidity. However, the consideration of these various approaches needs to be controlled by the S&L scope and Maker Governance. To date, the focus of S&L has been on collateral and not Dai. The prototype below is a test we composed to evaluate assumptions regarding how Maker Core or Maker SubDAOs could offer “Term Durations” to Dai holders. Term basically allows Maker Core or SubDAOs the ability to offer lock up options to DAI and sDAI holders, at the discretion of Maker, MKR holders, or SubDAO token holders. Prior to voting in the poll above, voters may want to review the documents and the prototype to consider the viability of such an approach. It seems such a product is possible, should Maker holders express a desire to pursue it. Perhaps the poll should be an expression of interest in the various approaches, rather than pitting one approach against the other in a binary fashion.    GitHub    GitHub - deco-protocol/term-dai Contribute to deco-protocol/term-dai development by creating an account on GitHub.

content.content: deco-cu:  Perhaps the poll should be an expression of interest in the various approaches, rather than pitting one approach against the other in a binary fashion.   Both Term Dai and notice accounts can coexist and play an important role in investment options. To clarify the first poll is intended to gauge whether notice accounts for the DSR would be attractive for DAI holders and our own goals, while the second poll seeks to facilitate a thoughtful discussion around both options and how they fit into Maker’s long term goals.
GPT-discussion-categories: Author of proposal is asking for feedback

content.content: I like this idea of notice accounts as an alternative to fixed term DSR instruments (eg DSR deposits maturing on specific dates). We’ve seen over the past few years that fixed rate protocols haven’t found much product market fit, and I believe one main reason for this is that people really don’t like being forced to roll over their positions manually - this introduces UX friction, additional gas costs, and complexity. This alternative mechanism would give users the experience of having positions automatically roll over until they wish to withdraw, which I think could be more attractive and result in a lower cost of capital to attract a given amount of DAI participation.

content.content: My vote was destined to maybe for a specific reason, I do not see so much sense in fixed terms but it would not be bad to experiment the term and time for it. 1 month doesn’t sound like a good time for UX, 6 months may change the picture by giving a little more confidence in these changing times.

3rd party extending to proposal

content.content: I would like to see Maker CDs. 6 months 1.5% APR and 12 month 2% APR. Create a truly decentralized yield curve.

Lack of PMF, along with the unknowns of whether there would be any fees or penalties associated with withdrawing DAI from the notice accounts before the notice period is over, couple that with what are the potential drawbacks or risks associated with offering notice accounts that could outweigh the benefits–polled for No. Agree here, that MakerDAO needs to have a discussion about how it plans to manage Dai liquidity and  this discussion should be part of the S&L scope meetings. Just our 2 gwei.

content.content: flipflopflapdelegate:  Lack of PMF, along with the unknowns of whether there would be any fees or penalties associated with withdrawing DAI from the notice accounts before the notice period is over,   The notice period starts when the client requests the funds. So a 30 day notice period has no maturity date until the clients requests the funds and then in 30 days the funds are liquid. Similar to unstaking periods. There can be scenarios were a client needs the funds before the notice period ends, in that case there can be penalties associated with early withdrawal such as a 30 day interest penalty     flipflopflapdelegate:  couple that with what are the potential drawbacks or risks associated with offering notice accounts that could outweigh the benefits–polled for No.   Sir, please provide more details about the drawbacks and risks

content.content: TRUEMAKER:  Do you believe that offering additional DSR options, such as notice accounts with different unwinding periods, would be attractive to DAI holders?   Voted No. What’s objectively most attractive for DAI holders is the safety and soundness of the Core protocol and its operations. Particular features or opportunities that might have appeal to certain segments of the market should not be dispositive of what MakerDAO should offer if the risks are otherwise unacceptable in the aggregate per MKR approved strategy and risk tolerance overall. Appreciate @flipflopflapdelegate and comments in other topics drawing focus around the Endgame constitutional process underway, which is a long and hard and painfully fought for mechanism to align the community and address all the questions about “what next?” and “how” regarding all the things.     flipflopflapdelegate:  Agree here, that MakerDAO needs to have a discussion about how it plans to manage Dai liquidity and this discussion should be part of the S&L scope meetings.   The focus and discipline required to transition to a sustainable steady state for the whole organization and MakerDAO ecosystem surely constrains a lot of what individuals or groups of individuals within and external to the DAO want to do and announce right now. Unnecessary frustration of efforts will arise from pushing forward with new products and features without the foundational blocks the transition pregame period seeks to implement. It’s counter-productive to keep MakerDAO in a perpetual state of moving internally at cross purposes without the proper sequencing of priorities and time for deliberation and consensus forming inputs. Crucial input here is certainly required from whichever Scope conversation will do analysis of regulatory resiliency, because the timing and optics are not great to have headlines on “yield” “APY” “income” offered to retail for investment. There are other conversations to have about DSR, what it is, how and why it works that can distinguish the technology from things in the hot seat right now. Let’s focus our planning and building and marketing in smart ways.

content.content: DaveringtonPLLC:  Voted No. What’s objectively most attractive for DAI holders is the safety and soundness of the Core protocol and its operations. Particular features or opportunities that might have appeal to certain segments of the market should not be dispositive of what MakerDAO should offer if the risks are otherwise unacceptable in the aggregate per MKR approved strategy and risk tolerance overall.   This DSR feature would allow more optionality not less. The instant access option would remain available but other options such as 7 day or 30 day notice periods would be available at a higher DSR. The notice period provides the protocol with additional safety measures as it has knowledge of withdrawals via notice to improve its liquidity.
